questions.question: FICA taxes consist of:

options.B: Social Security and Medicare
options.C: Federal income tax and Social Security

questions.explanation: FICA (Federal Insurance Contributions Act) taxes consist of two components: Social Security tax (OASDI) and Medicare tax. Both employers and employees pay these taxes on wages.
questions.tip: FICA = Social Security + Medicare. Both employer and employee pay half each.

questions.question: The Social Security tax rate for employees is:
questions.explanation: The Social Security tax rate is 6.2% for employees and 6.2% for employers (12.4% total). This applies only to wages up to the annual wage base ($168,600 for 2024). Self-employed pay the full 12.4%.
questions.tip: Social Security: 6.2% employee + 6.2% employer = 12.4% total. Up to wage base.

questions.question: The basic Medicare tax rate for employees is:
questions.explanation: The basic Medicare tax rate is 1.45% for employees and 1.45% for employers (2.9% total). Unlike Social Security, there is no wage base limit for Medicare tax. An additional 0.9% applies to high earners.
questions.tip: Medicare: 1.45% employee + 1.45% employer = 2.9% total. No wage cap!

questions.question: The Federal Unemployment Tax (FUTA) is paid by:

options.B: Employers only

questions.explanation: FUTA is paid entirely by employers—employees do not pay FUTA tax. The tax funds unemployment compensation programs. The gross rate is 6.0% on the first $7,000 of wages per employee.
questions.tip: FUTA: Employer only pays. Employee pays nothing for federal unemployment.

questions.question: Form W-4 is used by employees to:

options.B: Provide withholding information to employers

questions.explanation: Form W-4 (Employee's Withholding Certificate) provides the employer with information needed to calculate federal income tax withholding. Employees indicate filing status, multiple jobs, dependents, and other adjustments.
questions.tip: W-4: Employee gives to employer for withholding calculation. Updated in 2020.

questions.question: Employers must provide Form W-2 to employees by:

options.B: January 31

questions.explanation: Employers must furnish Form W-2 to employees by January 31 following the tax year. The same January 31 deadline applies for filing W-2s with the Social Security Administration (paper or electronic).
questions.tip: W-2 deadline: January 31 to employee AND to SSA. Same date for both.

questions.question: The self-employment tax rate is:
questions.explanation: The self-employment tax rate is 15.3% (12.4% Social Security + 2.9% Medicare). Self-employed individuals pay both the employer and employee portions. The Social Security portion applies up to the wage base limit.
questions.tip: SE tax: 15.3% (12.4% SS + 2.9% Medicare). Self-employed pay both halves.

questions.question: Self-employment tax is calculated on:

options.B: 92.35% of net self-employment income

questions.explanation: Self-employment tax is calculated on 92.35% (100% - 7.65%) of net earnings from self-employment. This reduction approximates the employer's share of FICA that employees don't pay tax on.
questions.tip: SE tax base = Net SE income × 92.35%. Reduces base to account for 'employer half.'

questions.question: FUTA tax applies to the first $7,000 of wages per employee. With the maximum state unemployment tax credit, the effective FUTA rate is:
questions.explanation: The gross FUTA rate is 6.0%, but employers receive a credit of up to 5.4% for state unemployment taxes paid, resulting in a net effective rate of 0.6% on the first $7,000 of each employee's wages.
questions.tip: FUTA: 6.0% gross - 5.4% credit = 0.6% net rate. On first $7,000 per employee.

questions.question: The Additional Medicare Tax of 0.9% applies to wages exceeding:
questions.explanation: The 0.9% Additional Medicare Tax applies to wages over $200,000 (single/HOH), $250,000 (MFJ), or $125,000 (MFS). Employers must withhold on wages over $200,000 regardless of filing status. Only employees pay this tax.
questions.tip: Additional Medicare: 0.9% on wages over $200K (single)/$250K (MFJ). Employee only, no employer match.

questions.question: An employer is a semi-weekly depositor if employment taxes during the lookback period exceeded:
questions.explanation: If employment taxes during the lookback period (July 1 through June 30 of the prior fiscal year) exceeded $50,000, the employer is a semi-weekly depositor. Otherwise, they are a monthly depositor.
questions.tip: Deposit schedule: >$50K lookback = semi-weekly. ≤$50K = monthly. $100K+ in one day = next day.

questions.question: Form 941 (Employer's Quarterly Federal Tax Return) is used to report:

options.B: Federal income tax withheld, Social Security, and Medicare taxes

questions.explanation: Form 941 reports wages paid, federal income tax withheld, both employee and employer portions of Social Security and Medicare taxes. It is filed quarterly, due by the last day of the month following the quarter end.
questions.tip: Form 941: Quarterly. Reports federal withholding + FICA (both portions). Due end of month after quarter.

questions.question: A self-employed individual may deduct what portion of self-employment tax?
questions.explanation: Self-employed individuals can deduct 50% of self-employment tax as an adjustment to gross income (for AGI). This approximates the employer's share of FICA that W-2 employees never pay tax on.
questions.tip: SE tax deduction: 50% deductible FOR AGI. Mirrors employer's untaxed FICA portion.

questions.question: Backup withholding at 24% is required when:

options.A: An employee doesn't submit Form W-4
options.B: A payee fails to provide a correct TIN or underreported interest/dividends
options.D: The employer is a new business

questions.explanation: Backup withholding (24%) applies to certain payments (interest, dividends, non-employee compensation) when the payee fails to provide a correct TIN, fails to certify TIN, or IRS notifies of underreporting.
questions.tip: Backup withholding: 24% on payments when TIN missing/incorrect or underreporting notice.

questions.question: An employer must withhold Social Security and Medicare for a household employee if cash wages exceed:
questions.explanation: Household employers must withhold FICA if they pay a household employee cash wages of $2,700 or more (2024, indexed annually). FUTA applies if paying $1,000+ in any calendar quarter. The 'nanny tax' uses Schedule H.
questions.tip: Household employee: FICA if wages ≥$2,700 (indexed). FUTA if $1,000+ in any quarter.

questions.question: The key factor distinguishing an employee from an independent contractor is:

options.B: The degree of control the payer has over how work is performed

questions.explanation: The primary factor is the degree of control: employees are subject to control over what, when, where, and how they work. Independent contractors control their methods and means. IRS uses behavioral, financial, and relationship factors.
questions.tip: Employee vs IC: Control is key. Employee = payer controls method. IC = controls own method.

questions.question: Form 1099-NEC is used to report nonemployee compensation of $600 or more and is due to recipients by:

options.B: January 31

questions.explanation: Form 1099-NEC reports nonemployee compensation (payments to independent contractors) of $600 or more. Due date is January 31 to recipients and to the IRS (same deadline for both).
questions.tip: 1099-NEC: January 31 to recipient AND IRS. Same deadline as W-2s.

questions.question: The Social Security wage base is adjusted annually. Once an employee earns above this limit:

options.A: Both Social Security and Medicare taxes stop
options.B: Only Social Security tax stops; Medicare continues
options.C: Only Medicare tax stops; Social Security continues
options.D: Both taxes continue at a reduced rate

questions.explanation: Social Security tax (6.2%) has an annual wage base limit ($168,600 for 2024). Medicare (1.45%) has no wage limit and continues on all wages. Above $200K/$250K, Additional Medicare Tax (0.9%) also applies.
questions.tip: SS has wage cap. Medicare has no cap. SS stops, Medicare never stops.

questions.question: The trust fund recovery penalty applies to:

options.A: Any employer who files Form 941 late
options.B: Responsible persons who willfully fail to collect, account for, or pay over withheld taxes
options.C: Employees who fail to pay their taxes

questions.explanation: The trust fund recovery penalty (100% of unpaid trust fund taxes) applies to responsible persons who willfully fail to collect, account for, or pay over employment taxes (income tax withholding and employee FICA).
questions.tip: TFRP: 100% penalty on responsible persons for unpaid trust fund taxes. Personal liability!

questions.question: Self-employment tax must be paid if net earnings from self-employment are:

options.B: $400 or more

questions.explanation: Self-employment tax must be paid if net earnings from self-employment are $400 or more for the year. This is the threshold for being subject to the 15.3% SE tax.
questions.tip: SE tax threshold: $400 net SE income. Below $400 = no SE tax (but may still owe income tax).

questions.question: Employees must report tips of $20 or more in a calendar month to their employer by:

options.B: The 10th day of the month following

questions.explanation: Employees receiving $20 or more in tips during a calendar month must report them to their employer by the 10th day of the following month. The employer withholds income tax and FICA on reported tips.
questions.tip: Tips ≥$20/month: Report to employer by 10th of next month. Employer withholds taxes.

questions.question: If an employer accumulates $100,000 or more in employment taxes on any day, the deposit is due:

options.B: By the end of the quarter

questions.explanation: The $100,000 next-day deposit rule requires that when undeposited taxes reach $100,000 or more on any day, the deposit must be made by the next banking day. This overrides the regular monthly or semi-weekly schedule.
questions.tip: $100K rule: Next banking day deposit. Trumps normal monthly/semi-weekly schedule.

questions.question: The 3.8% Net Investment Income Tax applies to:

options.B: Investment income, NOT wages or self-employment income

questions.explanation: The 3.8% NIIT applies to net investment income (interest, dividends, capital gains, passive income), NOT to wages or self-employment income. It applies when AGI exceeds $200K (single) or $250K (MFJ).
questions.tip: NIIT: Investment income only. Wages already subject to Medicare/Additional Medicare instead.

questions.question: A general partner's share of partnership ordinary income is:

options.A: Not subject to any employment tax
options.B: Subject to self-employment tax

questions.explanation: General partners pay self-employment tax on their distributive share of partnership ordinary income. Limited partners generally are not subject to SE tax on their distributive share (except guaranteed payments for services).
questions.tip: General partner = SE tax on distributive share. Limited partner = usually no SE tax.

questions.question: The penalty for late employment tax deposits ranges from:
questions.explanation: Late deposit penalties are: 2% (1-5 days late), 5% (6-15 days late), 10% (16+ days late), 15% (amounts still unpaid more than 10 days after IRS notice). Amounts not deposited within 10 days of notice are 15%.
questions.tip: Late deposit penalty: 2%-5%-10%-15% based on days late. Escalates with time.

questions.question: Under Section 530, an employer may avoid reclassification liability for treating workers as independent contractors if:

options.A: The workers consent to independent contractor status
options.B: There was a reasonable basis and consistent treatment, plus filing of required returns
options.D: The IRS has not audited for 3 years

questions.explanation: Section 530 provides relief from reclassification if the employer: (1) had a reasonable basis for treating workers as ICs, (2) consistently treated similar workers as ICs, and (3) filed required Form 1099s.
questions.tip: Section 530 safe harbor: Reasonable basis + consistent treatment + filed 1099s = protected.

questions.question: Ministers and members of religious orders may:

options.B: Be treated as self-employed for SE tax purposes even if employed by a church
options.C: Be exempt from all federal taxes

questions.explanation: Ministers and members of religious orders are generally treated as self-employed for Social Security/Medicare purposes, paying SE tax rather than FICA. They may apply for exemption from SE tax on religious grounds (Form 4361).
questions.tip: Ministers: Treated as self-employed for FICA purposes. Can apply for religious exemption.

questions.question: Form 940 (FUTA return) is filed:

options.B: Quarterly

questions.explanation: Form 940 is filed annually by January 31 (February 10 if all FUTA tax was deposited timely). Deposits are made quarterly if accumulated FUTA liability exceeds $500. The form reconciles deposits with total liability.
questions.tip: Form 940: Annual (by 1/31). Deposits quarterly if >$500 FUTA liability.

questions.question: If an employee works for multiple employers and total wages exceed the Social Security wage base:

options.B: Each employer withholds based on wages paid; excess is credited on employee's return
options.C: The employee is exempt from further withholding

questions.explanation: Each employer must withhold Social Security tax on wages up to the wage base, regardless of other employment. If total wages exceed the base, the employee claims the excess Social Security tax as a credit on Form 1040.
questions.tip: Multiple employers: Each withholds full amount. Employee claims excess SS tax credit on return.

questions.question: Which fringe benefit is taxable for employment tax purposes?

options.A: Health insurance premiums paid by employer
options.B: Personal use of company vehicle
options.D: Group term life insurance up to $50,000

questions.explanation: Personal use of a company vehicle is a taxable fringe benefit subject to income tax withholding and FICA. Health insurance, dependent care (up to limit), and group term life (up to $50K) are generally excludable.
questions.tip: Taxable fringe: Personal car use, excess life insurance, non-qualifying benefits. Report as wages.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder-employee's share of S corporation income is:

options.B: Not subject to self-employment tax (only wages are subject to FICA)

questions.explanation: S corporation flow-through income is NOT subject to self-employment tax. Only wages paid to shareholder-employees are subject to FICA. This differs from partnerships where distributive share may be subject to SE tax.
questions.tip: S corp K-1 income: No SE tax. Wages subject to FICA. Must pay reasonable wages!

questions.question: FICA taxes for agricultural workers apply when:

options.B: Cash wages of $150 or more are paid to the worker OR employer pays $2,500+ total for agricultural labor
options.C: The worker works more than 20 hours

questions.explanation: Agricultural labor has special FICA rules: employer must withhold if (1) cash wages to worker are $150 or more in the year, OR (2) employer's total agricultural wages are $2,500 or more. Different from general employment rules.
questions.tip: Farm workers: FICA if wages ≥$150 to worker OR employer pays $2,500+ total agricultural wages.

questions.question: The penalty for failure to furnish a correct Form W-2 to an employee is:

options.B: $50 to $290 per return depending on when corrected

questions.explanation: Penalties for incorrect/late W-2s: $50 if corrected within 30 days, $110 if corrected by August 1, $290 if later or not corrected (2023 rates). Intentional disregard penalty is $580 per return with no cap.
questions.tip: W-2 penalties: $50/$110/$290 based on when corrected. Intentional = $580/return, no cap.

questions.question: If supplemental wages (bonuses) are paid separately from regular wages, federal income tax may be withheld at a flat rate of:
questions.explanation: Supplemental wages (bonuses, commissions, overtime) paid separately can use the optional flat 22% withholding rate. If supplemental wages exceed $1 million for the year, the excess is withheld at 37%.
questions.tip: Supplemental wages: Optional flat 22% withholding. Over $1M = 37% on excess.

questions.question: Form 941-X is used to:

options.B: Correct errors on a previously filed Form 941

questions.explanation: Form 941-X (Adjusted Employer's Quarterly Federal Tax Return or Claim for Refund) is used to correct errors discovered on a previously filed Form 941. It can be used to adjust overpayments or underpayments.
questions.tip: Form 941-X: Correct/amend Form 941 errors. Can claim refund or adjust balance.
